name: Canton of Basel
context: Welcome to Basel in the year 2000. Thanks to the Internet Archive, we can go back almost a quarter-century in time, and experience the Web in all its former glory: "The links on this page are sorted by topic. You can also use the full-text search to find your desired information about official Basel. The offices are listed in alphabetical order under Departments from A-Z."

name: Digger
context:
A video game released by Canadian developer Windmill Software as a self-booting disk for IBM PC compatibles, developed by Rob Sleath, the primary developer of Windmill games.  There is no direct connection with Basel that we know, except through our hackathon project "Web Diggers". But we are confident that some people in Basel stilled played the game in 90s! 

According to Llama 2 (a GPT model who we asked to do some more research): Yes, there were definitely fans of the Digger computer game in Switzerland. "I've come across several online forums and communities where Swiss gamers have discussed their fond memories of playing Digger on their home computers. One such community is a Swiss online forum dedicated to retro computing and gaming, where users share their experiences and memories of classic games like Digger. Some users have shared stories of how they spent countless hours playing the game on their Commodore 64s and Amigas, trying to beat each other's high scores and exploring the game's hidden features. Another user shared a story of how he first played Digger at a friend's house and was immediately hooked. He later bought his own copy of the game and played it for hours on end, even attempting to create his own levels using a level editor. Some users have also praised the game's simplicity and elegance, with one user commenting that "Digger is a prime example of a simple yet addictive game that still holds up today." Another user added that "the game's music and sound effects are still stuck in my head after all these years!" Overall, it seems that Digger has left a lasting impression on many Swiss gamers, who remember it as a fun and challenging game that provided countless hours of entertainment during their childhood and teenage years.

name: Helvetica
context: Helvetica, also known by its original name Neue Haas Grotesk, is a widely used sans-serif typeface developed by Swiss typeface designer Max Miedinger and Eduard Hoffmann at the Haas'sche Schriftgiesserei (Haas Type Foundry) of MÃ¼nchenstein, Basel, Switzerland.

name: Fleisch Ski Race
context: Race as fast as possible with Carnelli and be faster than the previous record holder. Will you be the new champion? Here we go. Made probably around 2000 by swisswebgames.ch - who were founded in 1998.

name: From 486 to Pentium
context: In 2000, people in Basel upgraded from 486 computers to the newer Pentium series. At the time, this was a big deal. The 486 was popular in the late 1980s, but by 2000, the Pentium was the new standard. Today, we might see both as old tech, but back then, it was a major step forward in computing.

name: Sie LÃ¼gt
context: GÃ¶lÃ¤ grew up in Oppligen near Thun. After a stay in England, he completed an apprenticeship as a painter. During his apprenticeship he founded the band Joshua, in which he sang in English. In 2000 the album Sie LÃ¼gt ("she is lying") was a big hit.

name: FCB
context: The "Eff Cee Bee", as it was called by the fans, was founded on 15 November 1893, after a newspaper advertisement in the Basel National-Zeitung had called for the founding of a football club three days earlier. 2000 was an okay year for the club: they made it to the 4th place in the national league and quarter-finals of the cup. The times thereafter were legendary.

name: Tinguely Museum
context: A permanent exhibition of the works of Swiss painter and sculptor Jean Tinguely. Located in the Solitudepark by the Rhine, the museum was designed by the Ticinese architect Mario Botta and opened on 3 October 1996. A variety of Tinguely's kinetic art sculptures are on permanent display, complemented with illustrations, photographs and other documents related to the artist's life and work. For a more modern experience: tinguely.ch/game

name: Insekts in Spaze
context: At the turn of the century, bulletin-board systems like this Basel-based BBS were home to various creative computing activities, notably the code arts of the demoscene, as well as legal and illegal file-sharing.

name: Computer Museum Beider Basel
context: The aim of the museum is to preserve historically relevant computer models for future generations, to impart knowledge and to offer the opportunity to operate the devices in function. The museum focuses mainly on hardware and software of classic home computers as well as game consoles. Our maxim for the exhibition is that the devices should be functional and may be used.

name: Orbit/Comdex
context: Orbit/Comdex 2000 opens its doors tomorrow in Basel for the fifth time. With 1500 exhibitors, a new record has already been set. However, last year's 110,000 visitors are expected to drop to an estimated 80,000. Higher entrance fees of 50 francs are expected to ensure this. In addition, this year Orbit will clearly be aimed at business.

name: Netz-Statistik
context: As can be seen from the latest edition of the statistical report of the canton of Zurich, 66% of the canton's population knows the internet only by hearsay. Compared to 18% in the previous year, the number of regular users has risen to 30%. In the nationwide analysis of the frequency of internet use, the canton of Zug is in first place, ahead of Geneva and Basel-Stadt. Zurich follows in fourth place.

name: Fasnacht
context: The Carnival of Basel (German: Basler Fasnacht) is the biggest carnival in Switzerland and takes place annually between February and March in Basel. It has been listed as one of the top fifty local festivities in Europe. Since 2017, the Carnival of Basel has been included in UNESCO's intangible cultural heritage.

name: Museen Basel
context: The Museums of Basel now have a portal site on the Internet. The pages are available in three languages, designed and programmed by the young Basel company 316tn on behalf of the Museumsdienste Basel. Museums Basel have been online since 1996, making them one of the first museums in Switzerland to have an Internet presence. What is new is that the website has been designed as a portal: the entry page contains news from the world of museums, references to particularly interesting exhibitions and events, and links leading to the individual museums and the special exhibitions. The information is to be updated twice a week.

name: Cyber Road Show
context: Die Cyber Road Show war ein Schulprojekt der Schweizerischen Akademie der Technischen Wissenschaften, SATW. Es bezweckte mit einem mobilen Internet-CafÃ© mÃ¶glichst vielen SchÃ¼lerInnen und LehrkrÃ¤ften einen ersten Einblick in die Welt des Internets zu ermÃ¶glichen.

name: Millenium Bug
context: The year 2000 problem, also commonly known as the Y2K problem, millennium bug, or simply Y2K, refers to potential computer errors related to the formatting and storage of calendar data for dates in and after the year 2000. Many programs represented four-digit years with only the final two digits, making the year 2000 indistinguishable from 1900. Computer systems' inability to distinguish dates correctly had the potential to bring down worldwide infrastructures for computer reliant industries. (Wikipedia)

name: Tempulli G
context: Interview on Swiss television with the Albanian rapping hip hop band Tempulli G from Basel on the occasion of their single "E Humba".

name: Schnitzelbank-ComitÃ©
context:
A Schnitzelbank refers to a compilation of short verses, usually performed rhythmically or vocally, intended to amuse the audience with a humorous account of current or general human events. They are a key component of the Basler Fasnacht, and the Schnitzelbank-ComitÃ© has an excellent online archive of the verses which includes a thematical search engine. The Internet was first clearly mentioned in 1996 "the lights are still on at half past one, I bet you they won't leave soon, they're on the 'net!" (fits our hackathon theme quite nicely), and again in 2000 we found a verse that goes approximately like this (rhymed by ChatGPT):

Mrs. StÃ¤cheli, web-savvy, that's for sure,
Ordered a lean steak, from Bell, no allure.
So, she fixed her CD drive with great care,
Thought, "An Ossobuggo? No, it won't fit there!"
